article.title: On asymptotic normality of certain linear rank statistics

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main focus of the scientific article "On asymptotic normality of certain linear rank statistics"?
choices: Analyzing the efficiency of different clinical trial designs.
Deriving conditions for the asymptotic normality of linear rank statistics under various randomization rules.
Developing new randomization rules for clinical trials with two treatment groups.
Comparing the performance of different scoring rules for linear rank statistics.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does  `P(Tn,j = tj | Tn,j−1 = tj−1,..., Tn,1 = t1)` represent in the context of randomization rules?
choices: The probability of assigning the j-th patient to the treatment group given the assignments of all previous patients.
The probability of observing a specific sequence of treatment assignments for the first j patients.
The expected difference in treatment group sizes after j patients have been randomized.
The variance of the linear rank statistic after j patients have been randomized.

multiple_choice_question.text: Under what condition does Theorem 2.1 guarantee the asymptotic normality of Sn?
choices: The maximum absolute value of the centered and scaled scores (`Zn,j`) converges to 0.
The sum of squared centered and scaled scores (`Zn,j`) converges to 1 in probability.
The conditional expectation of `Tn,j` given the past is always 0.
All of the above conditions must hold.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using Proposition 2.3 compared to Theorem 2.2 when dealing with randomization rules in clinical trials?
choices: Proposition 2.3 provides a more general result that applies to a wider range of randomization rules.
Proposition 2.3 simplifies the verification of asymptotic normality by directly using conditional probabilities of the randomization rule.
Proposition 2.3 does not require any constraints on the scores (`an,j`) used in the linear rank statistic.
Proposition 2.3 always leads to a closed-form expression for the asymptotic variance of the linear rank statistic.
